- Introduction to the MAP meta-model for intentional process modeling.
- Case study applications of the intention-oriented approach.

- Analysis of BPM limitations and how state-oriented paradigms can address them.

IBI;Cours obligatoire;M2-GO: AI law, AI Ethics;30;0;Camille;;;AI law and ethics;This course explores the legal and ethical frameworks surrounding the development, deployment, and use of Artificial Intelligence systems. Building on the legal foundations acquired in M1, it focuses on the specific challenges raised by AI technologies in terms of accountability, transparency, data protection, discrimination risks, and human rights. Students will examine emerging legal instruments—such as the European Union AI Act—as well as ethical guidelines and governance models developed by international bodies. The course emphasizes critical reflection, regulatory compliance, and the ability to design AI systems aligned with legal obligations and ethical values.;At the end of this course
column2: students shall be able to identify and analyze the legal frameworks applicable to AI systems
column3: including sector-specific regulations and the AI Act.

column1: At the end of this course
column2: students shall be able to assess the ethical risks associated with the development and use of AI technologies and apply key principles such as fairness

column1: At the end of this course
column2: students shall be able to integrate legal and ethical considerations into the design
column4: and governance of AI systems.";yes;"General knowledge of legal concepts and regulations
column5: as acquired in the M1 Law course.
